We don’t know for a fact that “the Russians” are using a nerve agent that can be traced, but we don’t have a better explanation for what happened. Russian officials and media tried hard to come up with alternative explanations, but they could not think of anything better than to blame the UK for poisoning someone of value to the UK on the UK soil with a nerve agent that does not have any particular UK connections. I guess, Putin was too smart not to blame the Martians. In politics, many things are done for game-theoretic reasons, in other words, responding to something, trying to anticipate events, or trying to trigger a particular response. In particular, propaganda often works this way - it really does not matter how nonsensical their material may be, what matters is how people respond. In this particular case, the argument (to the West) is that Russia could not have done this because the effect is not in their favor. That’s a rotten argument because Russia and the Soviet Union (whose heir Russia proudly is) made many historical mistakes. For example, Stalin stubbornly refused many independent and highly-credible warnings that the Nazi Germany would invade on June 22, 1941. Instead, he moved troops, tanks and planes, very close to the border, making them vulnerable to air raids and capture, which happened in spades (Stalin was apparently shocked for several days before he composed himself and addressed the nation). In modern times, Russia’s relations with the Baltic countries, Poland and Ukraine are another example of massive shortsightedness. For example, Russia used to be the exclusive supplier of natural gas to Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Ukraine, charging exorbitant prices and insisting on their monopoly. Now that Lithuania and Poland are operating LNG terminals, prices have dropped considerably. Ukraine reversed pipelines and is buying natgas from Norway and other countries, also forcing Russia to dramatically lower gas prices. Anyway, back to nerve agents. Given that the poisoning occurred shortly before the presidential elections, it probably served several goals. One was to warn the opposition not to upset the elections and not to question its legitimacy. The election wasn’t particularly clean - Russian Observers Charge Fraud in Putin’s Landslide Re-Election - so, there are many reasons to protest, just as 2011–2013 Russian protests after Putin’s previous elections. At that time, opposition leaders were arrested quickly, but the legal proceedings were lengthy and messy. It is in Putin’s best interests to prevent a repeat of those events. Given the somewhat unexpected development, where China approved 'president for life' change, Putin will now be tempted to push similar changes in the Russian Constitution. However, that would require a very strong mandate. Lo and behold, statistical analysis indicates massive fraud - Seeing 'Churov's Saw': Russian Researcher Says Putin May Have Received 10 Million Fraudulent Votes. This wouldn’t be a huge change from [1205.0741] Statistical anomalies in 2011-2012 Russian elections revealed by 2D correlation analysis To summarize, the use of a traceable nerve agent can mean that Putin wanted to send a message to people like Skripal and their associates - we can kill you anywhere. That mission has been accomplished. Of course, for everyone else, Putin would like to have deniability. The British aptly called this state of things “implausible deniability”.
